David Scull, Republican candidate for congressman-at-large,
will speak in the Sherwood Room
of Levering Hall this coming
Tuesday at 4:00. The speech will
be sponsored by the Hopkins
Young Republican Club.
Mr. Scull, 47, is the only Republican candidate in Maryland
who has yet refused to support
Republican presidential nominee

Barry Goldwater. A former
Montgomery County and State
Republican Chairman, he claims
to be "a common sense moderate
to represent all Marylanders."
His slogan is "no bosses—no
deals—no strings", anl he stands
for "decentralized power, a firm
foreign policy, economy in government, and equal opportunity."

STEP FORWARD
WITH FORD MOTOR COMPANY
An Open Letter to the 1965
College Graduate
from Donald N. Frey,
Assistant General Manager,
Ford Division of
Ford Motor Company

American politics. There are issues that should be discussed in
terms of the realities of an industrial age but remain ignored
or rhetorically absorped—the
massive concentration of economic power into the hands of
a few corporations, the progressive economic dislocation of large
segments ofthe population (automation, poverty ,etc.), the
birth of new nuclear powers that
are there whether we choose to
recognize them or not, revolutions at home demanding a share
of the social goods of America,
revolutions abroad over-throwing U.S.! supported reactionary
puppets of imperialism in Asia
and Latin America. Instead of
Bobby Baker, we should be talking about automation that is
eliminating jobs at a rate of 2
million per year, instead of the
immorality of topless bathing
suits lumped
together with
"crime in the streets," we should
be discussing the poverty, prisons
and ghetto hell-holes that breed
crime as the only escape from
these prisons; instead of allowing
Johnson and the liberal establishment to offer programs that
are either pitifully inadequate at
home (e.g., "War on Poverty")
or are dangerously reactionary
abroad (e.g., Vietnam) and that
go unchallenged by all but the
most socially irrelevant and politically dangerous groups in
American, we should the beginning of a real dialogue in American politics.

Donald N. Frey was awarded a bachelor's degree in metallurgical engineering by the University of Michigan in 1947
and a doctorate in 1950. One year later, he joined Ford
Motor Company as manager of the Metallurgical Department in the Scientific Laboratory. In 1962, Dr. Frey was
appointed assistant general manager of the Ford Division
with responsibility for all engineering, product planning
and purchasing activities. He is 41 years old.

America's automobile industry is in the midst of a challenging era, with prospects of an even more exciting and demanding tempo in the years to come.
Ford Motor Company is determined to achieve leadership in all phases of its
operation. This leadership promises to bring lasting success to the company, its
employes and its stockholders.
It will take people to accomplish this objective. Engineering, finance, styling,
marketing, product planning, sales—all require people with the knowledge,
judgment and personal drive to avail themselves of the unprecedented opportunities offered by a great industry.
The automobile business is growing. More cars are being bought now than ever
before. With increases in population and consumer buying power, even more
will be bought in the future. Realizing this, Ford Motor Company seeks to
attract college graduates who have the capacity to grow with the company
and the market.
Right now, our plans call for employing about a thousand of the best 1965
graduates we can find, with all types of educational backgrounds. We need
specialists, but we also need persons with broad liberal-arts training who can
handle a wide variety of assignments. Actually, in our company, many graduates grow into jobs totally unrelated to their degrees. They have discovered
that Ford offers intellectually challenging opportunities for those with the
ability to seize them. We invite you to make the same discovery.
Contact your Placement Office and arrange to see our representative.

peace and that man must demonstrate his humanity to man.
Admission will be free.

Barry and Friends
The cancellation of Senator Goldwater's scheduled
address here elicited mixed reactions on the Homewood
campus. A few were disappointed. Most just didn't seem
to care. It would have been nice to hear a presidential
candidate, especially one who is apparently the prophet
of a philosophy that seems alien to the consensus that
has governed this country for the last 20 years.
It would have been nice, but not vitally important;
for Senator Goldwater apparently would have little to
say to an academic group. His campaign is aimed at
stimulating emotion rather than thought.
All problems can he solved by firm will and moral
leadership, or so Senator Goldwater would have us believe. For example, he and other Republicans imply
that if the Senator were elected he would use his moral
leadership and firm will to eradicate crime throughout the
nation. We would find Republican pleas (they cannot
be called arguments, for reason is the essence of argument) more appealing if Senator Goldwater had used
his moral leadership in his own state of Arizona; but
Phoenix, the state capital, has one of the highest crime
rates in the nation.
Senator Goldwater is not without some virtues,
however (He does look good riding a horse.). The
same cannot be said of his running mate, Representative
William Miller. Miller is known as a "gut-fighter," a
term applied to those who, having neither ideas of their
own nor the ability to comprehend the ideas of others,
make their way in the world by attacking the evil traits,
real and imagined, of their opponents. Miller does deserve some sympathy, for he is faced with the onerous
tasks of defending Senator Goldwater's indefensible
positions.
Senator Goldwater and Miller have had the advantage of the counsel of Dean Burch, the Republican
National Committee Chairman. Burch will best be remembered for his performance following President
Johnson's televised address last Sunday. In making his
invalid demands for equal time, Burch acted somewhat
Eke a six year old who had had his lollipop taken away.
We would suggest that Burch's lollipop be returned immediately; even he would find it hard to talk with a
lollipop in his mouth.
Senator Goldwater, Miller, and Burch are by no
means the strangest Republicans around. Earlier this
week a citizens for Goldwater committee made known
Ma plans for a film that would document the moral
decline of the nation under the Democratic party. As
examples of the decline in our moral fibre, the Repubbeans planned to include shots of strip-tease dancers
and topless bathing suits. It must sound odd, but in our
blissful undergraduate ignorance, we had thought that
strip-teasers were around long before 1960. In any case,
M the Republicans can prove that Democrats are responsible for strip-tease dances and topless bathing suits,
die Democrats will have the News-Letter endorsement.
These 1964 Republicans sure are a "curious crew."

Goldman's View
With Eric Goldman scheduled to speak here Sunday, The editors felt it appropriate to reprint an excerpt of a column written by Dr. Goldman for the
January 22, 1934 News-Letter. In the column, which is
timely even today, he answers another student's earlier

"You have renounced any concrete purpose in
Eying, your most compelling aspiration is to understand everything without being a part of it, your armored

serious fellows sonorously dub the serious problems of
the world, you have only the most flippant condescension.

Broca's previous films (The
Joker, The Love Game), its location, style, and theme are
wildly different. Paris has been
replaced by the wilds of Brazil,
leisurely pace changed to breakneck speed, and elements of the
chase, mystery, and suspense
added to romance. With a small
cast and high good humor De
Broca has produced what Stanley Kramer, 23 comedians, and
the giant screen of Its a Mad,
Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad world
could not: a film that never sits
still, that is light, exciting, and
exceptionally funny. In Kramer's
film, action is motivated, and
character corrupted, by universal
greed; in Rio, action is motivated by love. The journey of
the lovers, from her pleasant
home in Paris to the heart of
the Brazilian jungle, is essentially a journey into love; the further fromthe distractions of civilization and the greater their
danger, the more fully is their
love realized.
The New West
The story is concerned with
the theft of a Brazilian statue
from a museum in Paris (one of
three such statues), the kidnapping of the museum's director
(who knows the secret of the
statues), the kidnapping of a
young woman (who knows the
location of the second statue),
the hunt for a Brazilian millionaire who has the third statue),
and a series of chases that extend from Paris to Rio to Brazilia
to a river port in the interior
to a jungle waterfall.
The film is largely derived in
style and theme from American
pictures; there is nothing in
French film history that suggests
it. The sparse dialogue and fast
pace, the economy of means, the
quick, direct action, and the interest in machines in motion are
all reminiscent of the films of
Hawks and Ford. To find a
frontier, that unique combination of open space and hostile
environment, De Broca went to

Brazil (as previously Hawks had
gone to Africa to film Hatari
and Huston to Mexico to film
The Treasure of Sierra Madre);
discovering in the dry plains, the
rugged, jerry-built towns, and
the jungle the equivalent of the
American frontier. There is also
a saloon brawl that is equal in
violence, duration, and humor to
any ever filmed in the Hollywood
west.
Belmont% and Dorleac
The acting in the film is excellent. Belmondo. as the soldier
whose fiancee is kidnapped, is
perfectly cast; physically believable in the part, he performs
with inspiration and energy.
Walking, running, swimming,
fighting, wrecking, motorcycles,
dragged behind boats, and bailing out of airplanes he is persistent, tireless, and brave. Francoise Dorleac, as the fiancee he
twice rescues from thieves, is
everything one could wish. She
is young and innocent, wonderfully beautiful, and the epitome
of grace and style. Jean Servais
as the museum director is suitably refined and corrupt.
Technical
The color photography by
Raoul Coutard has depth, clarity, and real feeling for composition and design; it is the most
creative I have seen since Black
Orpheus. Tight editing and numerous tracking shots contribute
to the film's fast pace and sense
of continuous motion. Music is
used sparingly and effectively
and is a various as the locations
of the film.

Gridders End Drought, 27-6
By JIM MONGIARDO
The long victory drought has
ended. With a 27-6 victory over
Haverford last Saturday, Hopkins
will take into tomorrow's home
contest with Randalph-Macon its
first win in two years.
Having lost fourteen previous
Contests and tying one before the
Greyhound game, the Jays will
be up against another strong
squad tomorrow. According to
coach Wilson Fewster, RandolphMacon, sporting a 1-3 record, has
"gained experience in four tough
games that is bound to be helpful to them. The Yellowjackets
have a fine running quarterback,
Charles Rippone, who can throw
the ball, and two big backs."
Randolph-Macon is strong
physically, playing two units.
Besides a strong bench, the Yellowjackets have a line which is
much bigger than that of Haverford.
Jays Dominate
In the Greyhound contest,
Hopkins, which had almost forgotten what victory was like, dominated the game from beginning to end. The Jays sported a
21-0 lead at the half.
A fumble recovery by Jim Landon started Hopkins on its way
in the first quarter. With the ball
on the Haverford 23, Jerry Pfeifer giuded the team into paydirt
in nine plays. Pass interference
in the end zone set up the score.
Pass Scores

one yard line failed, Pfeifer
flipped a short T.D. pass to Steve
Reynolds. Gerry kicked
the
seventh point.

a 56-yard pass-run play to end

By MARSHALL PAUL
The varsity cross-country team
visits Franklin and Marschall tomorrow in its fourth meet of the
season, but still may not be ready
to show form equal to its potential.
As of Tuesday, the Jays were
winless and two top men, Kevin

sidelined with injuries for two
weeks.
Murphy is still out and though
Clark may be in action tomorrow,
it is doubtful that he will be in
top shape, having had almost no
practice since he suffered a
pulled leg muscle.
Loomis Takes Third
Jack Loomis, a sophomore, and
John Sopka, a junior, have taken
up the slack somewhat, finishing
a strong third and fourth respectively, in Saturday's triangular meet here with Haverford
and Loyola.

David Scull, Republican candidate for congressman-at-large,
will speak in the Sherwood Room
of Levering Hall this coming
Tuesday at 4:00. The speech will
be sponsored by the Hopkins
Young Republican Club.
Mr. Scull, 47, is the only Republican candidate in Maryland
who has yet refused to support
Republican presidential nominee

Barry Goldwater. A former
Montgomery County and State
Republican Chairman, he claims
to be "a common sense moderate
to represent all Marylanders."
His slogan is "no bosses—no
deals—no strings", anl he stands
for "decentralized power, a firm
foreign policy, economy in government, and equal opportunity."

Donald N. Frey was awarded a bachelor's degree in metallurgical engineering by the University of Michigan in 1947
and a doctorate in 1950. One year later, he joined Ford
Motor Company as manager of the Metallurgical Department in the Scientific Laboratory. In 1962, Dr. Frey was
appointed assistant general manager of the Ford Division
with responsibility for all engineering, product planning
and purchasing activities. He is 41 years old.

America's automobile industry is in the midst of a challenging era, with prospects of an even more exciting and demanding tempo in the years to come.
Ford Motor Company is determined to achieve leadership in all phases of its
operation. This leadership promises to bring lasting success to the company, its
employes and its stockholders.
It will take people to accomplish this objective. Engineering, finance, styling,
marketing, product planning, sales—all require people with the knowledge,
judgment and personal drive to avail themselves of the unprecedented opportunities offered by a great industry.
The automobile business is growing. More cars are being bought now than ever
before. With increases in population and consumer buying power, even more
will be bought in the future. Realizing this, Ford Motor Company seeks to
attract college graduates who have the capacity to grow with the company
and the market.
Right now, our plans call for employing about a thousand of the best 1965
graduates we can find, with all types of educational backgrounds. We need
specialists, but we also need persons with broad liberal-arts training who can
handle a wide variety of assignments. Actually, in our company, many graduates grow into jobs totally unrelated to their degrees. They have discovered
that Ford offers intellectually challenging opportunities for those with the
ability to seize them. We invite you to make the same discovery.
Contact your Placement Office and arrange to see our representative.

Barry and Friends
The cancellation of Senator Goldwater's scheduled
address here elicited mixed reactions on the Homewood
campus. A few were disappointed. Most just didn't seem
to care. It would have been nice to hear a presidential
candidate, especially one who is apparently the prophet
of a philosophy that seems alien to the consensus that
has governed this country for the last 20 years.
It would have been nice, but not vitally important;
for Senator Goldwater apparently would have little to
say to an academic group. His campaign is aimed at
stimulating emotion rather than thought.
All problems can he solved by firm will and moral
leadership, or so Senator Goldwater would have us believe. For example, he and other Republicans imply
that if the Senator were elected he would use his moral
leadership and firm will to eradicate crime throughout the
nation. We would find Republican pleas (they cannot
be called arguments, for reason is the essence of argument) more appealing if Senator Goldwater had used
his moral leadership in his own state of Arizona; but
Phoenix, the state capital, has one of the highest crime
rates in the nation.
Senator Goldwater is not without some virtues,
however (He does look good riding a horse.). The
same cannot be said of his running mate, Representative
William Miller. Miller is known as a "gut-fighter," a
term applied to those who, having neither ideas of their
own nor the ability to comprehend the ideas of others,
make their way in the world by attacking the evil traits,
real and imagined, of their opponents. Miller does deserve some sympathy, for he is faced with the onerous
tasks of defending Senator Goldwater's indefensible
positions.
Senator Goldwater and Miller have had the advantage of the counsel of Dean Burch, the Republican
National Committee Chairman. Burch will best be remembered for his performance following President
Johnson's televised address last Sunday. In making his
invalid demands for equal time, Burch acted somewhat
Eke a six year old who had had his lollipop taken away.
We would suggest that Burch's lollipop be returned immediately; even he would find it hard to talk with a
lollipop in his mouth.
Senator Goldwater, Miller, and Burch are by no
means the strangest Republicans around. Earlier this
week a citizens for Goldwater committee made known
Ma plans for a film that would document the moral
decline of the nation under the Democratic party. As
examples of the decline in our moral fibre, the Repubbeans planned to include shots of strip-tease dancers
and topless bathing suits. It must sound odd, but in our
blissful undergraduate ignorance, we had thought that
strip-teasers were around long before 1960. In any case,
M the Republicans can prove that Democrats are responsible for strip-tease dances and topless bathing suits,
die Democrats will have the News-Letter endorsement.
These 1964 Republicans sure are a "curious crew."

Goldman's View
With Eric Goldman scheduled to speak here Sunday, The editors felt it appropriate to reprint an excerpt of a column written by Dr. Goldman for the
January 22, 1934 News-Letter. In the column, which is
timely even today, he answers another student's earlier
eolumn which was critical of current trends in higher
education.
"You have renounced any concrete purpose in
Eying, your most compelling aspiration is to understand everything without being a part of it, your armored
aloofness is a constant reminder of your attitude that
aH the world's a zoo and anyone belongs in the cages
who is unwilling or unable to stand aside distinterestwily and chuckle. You are so tolerant of everything that
you are intolerant of conviction. Woman for you, I do
not doubt, is a perapatetic pudenda, inconveniently encumbered with minds, flesh, and clothing. You are so
madly in pursuit of pleasure that you will rarely be
sure that you have found any and never have time to
heartily enjoy it. You will probably spend nine-tenths
of your time being bored and the other tenth describing
that feeling to your friends. As for what we pottering
serious fellows sonorously dub the serious problems of
the world, you have only the most flippant condescension.
Probably you see the whole squalid mess as inherently
Insoluble and you calculate the best vantage point as
somewhere on the high level of your aloofness from
which the view is amusing and the odor, if not negligible, is at lest least tolerable as a price for the show."

Broca's previous films (The
Joker, The Love Game), its location, style, and theme are
wildly different. Paris has been
replaced by the wilds of Brazil,
leisurely pace changed to breakneck speed, and elements of the
chase, mystery, and suspense
added to romance. With a small
cast and high good humor De
Broca has produced what Stanley Kramer, 23 comedians, and
the giant screen of Its a Mad,
Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad world
could not: a film that never sits
still, that is light, exciting, and
exceptionally funny. In Kramer's
film, action is motivated, and
character corrupted, by universal
greed; in Rio, action is motivated by love. The journey of
the lovers, from her pleasant
home in Paris to the heart of
the Brazilian jungle, is essentially a journey into love; the further fromthe distractions of civilization and the greater their
danger, the more fully is their
love realized.
The New West
The story is concerned with
the theft of a Brazilian statue
from a museum in Paris (one of
three such statues), the kidnapping of the museum's director
(who knows the secret of the
statues), the kidnapping of a
young woman (who knows the
location of the second statue),
the hunt for a Brazilian millionaire who has the third statue),
and a series of chases that extend from Paris to Rio to Brazilia
to a river port in the interior
to a jungle waterfall.
The film is largely derived in
style and theme from American
pictures; there is nothing in
French film history that suggests
it. The sparse dialogue and fast
pace, the economy of means, the
quick, direct action, and the interest in machines in motion are
all reminiscent of the films of
Hawks and Ford. To find a
frontier, that unique combination of open space and hostile
environment, De Broca went to

Brazil (as previously Hawks had
gone to Africa to film Hatari
and Huston to Mexico to film
The Treasure of Sierra Madre);
discovering in the dry plains, the
rugged, jerry-built towns, and
the jungle the equivalent of the
American frontier. There is also
a saloon brawl that is equal in
violence, duration, and humor to
any ever filmed in the Hollywood
west.
Belmont% and Dorleac
The acting in the film is excellent. Belmondo. as the soldier
whose fiancee is kidnapped, is
perfectly cast; physically believable in the part, he performs
with inspiration and energy.
Walking, running, swimming,
fighting, wrecking, motorcycles,
dragged behind boats, and bailing out of airplanes he is persistent, tireless, and brave. Francoise Dorleac, as the fiancee he
twice rescues from thieves, is
everything one could wish. She
is young and innocent, wonderfully beautiful, and the epitome
of grace and style. Jean Servais
as the museum director is suitably refined and corrupt.
Technical
The color photography by
Raoul Coutard has depth, clarity, and real feeling for composition and design; it is the most
creative I have seen since Black
Orpheus. Tight editing and numerous tracking shots contribute
to the film's fast pace and sense
of continuous motion. Music is
used sparingly and effectively
and is a various as the locations
of the film.
